metadata.title: High-Performance Hierarchical Black-Phosphorous-Based Soft Electrochemical Actuators in Bioinspired Applications

sections.text:
CommuniCation
1806492 (1 of 11) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.advmat.de

sections.heading: Soft Electrochemical Actuators in Bioinspired Applications
Guan Wu,* Xingjiang Wu, Yijun Xu, Hengyang Cheng, Jinku Meng, Qiang Yu,
Xinyiao Shi, Kai Zhang, Wei Chen, and Su Chen*
sections.text:
Dr. G. Wu, X. Wu, H. Cheng, J. Meng, Prof. S. Chen State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering College of Chemical Engineering Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals and Functional Polymer Materials Nanjing Tech University Nanjing 210009, P. R. China E-mail: gwu2016@njtech.edu.cn; chensu@njtech.edu.cn Dr. Y. Xu, Q. Yu, X. Shi, Prof. K. Zhang, Prof. W. Chen i-Lab Suzhou Institute of Nano-tech and Nano-bionics Chinese Academy of Sciences Suzhou 215123, P. R. China
The ORCID identification number(s) for the author(s) of this article can be found under https://doi.org/10.1002/adma.201806492.
DOI: 10.1002/adma.201806492
migration into/out of electrodes (such as ordered alignment,[2] hierarchical porous,[3] and anisotropic arrangement[4]) and polymer supported electrolyte layers (such as single-ion conducting,[5] nanostructured microphase-separated,[6] and interpenetrating[7] polymers) have become important subjects in biomimetic technologies. In particular, soft ionic actuators, also called electrochemical actuators, composed of one ion-conductive electrolyte layer sandwiched between two electrode layers,[8] have been intensively investigated in intelligent sensors, artificial muscles, smart robotics, and microelectromechanical systems.[9] Such electrochemical actuators would generate large strain, fast response, and air working durability combining with lightweight, high flexibility, and low voltage.[3,10] However, limited to the ion long-distance diffusion process,[11] construction of electrochemical actuators with a large deformation and a fast response time at the micro-to-nanoscale manipulation remains challenging.
The actuation deformations in electrochemical actuators are usually produced
by reversible ion intercalation and deintercalation into/out of electrodes. Namely, the enhancement of an electrode’s storage charges (ions) through an interfacial electrostatic double-layer effect[12] plays a major role in developing a new-generation highperformance actuator. To this end, the development of high-performance electrode materials with fast ion transportation and excess storage is highly needed. Specifically, the utilization of typically conductive carbon nanomaterials,[13] including carbon nanotubes (CNTs),[14] graphene,[15] graphdiyne,[16] and graphitic carbon,[7] is mainly concerned. For instance, the vertical-aligned electrode’s interfaces[17] or entire networks,[2] which provide ordered and continuous ionic path channels for ion short-range and quick diffusion, gave the actuator faster strain speed and stress rates (>8% s−1 and 12 MPa s−1, respectively). Stable nanoporous networks with densely packed structures[4] that supply a high ion-accessible surface enabled the actuator with a large actuation strain (>0.2%) and high cyclic stability.[18] Molecularscale manipulation of active electrodes enhanced the actuation performance (strain 0.78%) by the molecular bond transition, such as alkene–alkyne complex transition of graphdiyne.[16] On the other hand, electrochemically active materials such as heteroatoms doping[19] (N, S), conducting polymer[20] (polyaniline,
Bioinspired methods allowing artificial actuators to perform controllably are potentially important for various principles and may offer fundamental insight into chemistry and engineering. To date, the main challenges persist regarding the achievement of large deformation in fast response-time and potentialengineering applications in which electrode materials and structures limit ion diffusion and accumulation processes. Herein, a novel electrochemical actuator is developed that presents both higher electro mechanical performances and biomimetic applications based on hierachically structured covalently bridged black phosphorous/carbon nanotubes. The new actuator demonstrates astonishing actuation properties, including low power consumption/ strain (0.04 W cm−2 %−1), a large peak-to-peak strain (1.67%), a controlled frequency response (0.1–20 Hz), faster strain and stress rates (11.57% s−1; 28.48 MPa s−1), high power (29.11 kW m−3), and energy (8.48 kJ m−3) densities, and excellent cycling stability (500 000 cycles). More importantly, bioinspired applications such as artificial-claw, wings-vibrating, bionic-flower, and hand actuators have been realized. The key to high performances stems from hierachically structured materials with an ordered lamellar structure, large redox activity, and electrochemical capacitance (321.4 F g−1) for ions with smooth diffusion and flooding accommodation, which will guide substantial progress of next-generation electrochemical actuators.

sections.heading: Actuators
sections.text:
Ions in tissue perform versatile functions, including signal transduction of nerves, controlling living processes of muscle, and executing ordered micromotion and macrodeformation of tissue; thus, they play a key role in the life activities of organisms.[1] Until now, various efforts concerning the ion response to artificial muscle of bionic function by manipulating ion
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1806492
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1806492 (2 of 11)
polypyrrole), and metal oxides (NiO2,[21] MnO2,[22] RuO2[23]) were modified or incorporated into/on electrodes. The actuation performances were increased several times by active sitetriggered quantum capacitances and redox reaction–caused pseudocapacitances. However, the structural stability and interfacial charge transfer of actuators are not ideal, limiting their further applications.
Recently, black phosphorous (BP), a new class of noncarbon 2D nanomaterials, has been demonstrated to possess strong in-plane bonds, weaker van der Waals interaction, high carrier mobility, and highly anisotropic properties.[24] It has been applied to enhance the performance of devices, including lithium/sodium-ion batteries,[25] supercapacitors,[26] and electrocatalysts.[27] Additionally, BP has a tuneable bandgap with a thickness dependence, which can be managed from 0.3 eV for bulk to 2 eV for the monolayer.[28] More importantly, the interlayer spacing (0.54 nm) of BP that is larger than that of graphite at 0.34 nm and comparable to that of the 1T phase MoS2[29] at 0.62 nm endows 2D-layered structural materials with easier ion intercalation/deintercalation and fast diffusion. Those unique properties of BP with both structural advantage and electrochemical activity make it ideal for potential applications, especially in electrochemical supercapacitors. For example, Liu et al. first reported liquid-exfoliated BP nanoflakes with high a packing density as a supercapacitor electrode that displayed a larger energy density than that of graphene owing to the rapid charge/discharge ability.[26] Faster ion diffusion and intercalation in BP nanosheets could cause enhancement of the specific capacitance and cycling stability.[30] The surface functional group on BP layers acting as additionally trapping sites[31] could effectively facilitate charge storage with boosted ion transportation and adsorption.[32] Among these strikingly intrinsic properties, the key features of the 2D lamellar structure with a larger spacing and electrochemical activity can favor ion quick insertion/exaction, flooding storage, and huge volume change, which may directly reinforce the actuation deformation. However, the reported smart high-performance electrochemical actuators are still sparse, accounting for the shortage of robust actuation materials and assembly techniques. Therefore, the construction of ideal artificial actuators that can match biomimetic ones remains a great challenge.
In this work, for the first time, we designed and developed a high-performance electrochemical actuator made of robust hierachically structured and covalently bridged black phosphorous/carbon nanotubes (BP-CNTs) that can realize potentially bio mimetic applications. The new actuator exhibits low power consumption/strain (0.04 W cm−2 %−1), a large peak-to-peak deformation (displacement 21.4 mm; strain 1.67%), a controlled frequency response (0.1–20 Hz), faster strain and stress rates (11.57% s−1; 28.48 MPa s−1), high power (29.11 kW m−3) and energy (8.48 kJ m−3) densities, and excellent cycling-stability (5 × 105 cycles). The robust properties of actuations are ascribed to the BP-CNT materials associated with hierarchical 2D/1D structures, layered electrical conduction, mechanical backbone stability, and large electrochemical capacitances (321.4 F g−1). Based on these remarkable features, the artificial-claw-, wing-vibrating-, bionic-flower-, and handactuator-based soft robots have been successfully achieved. This strategy offers an available pathway to design high-performance
electrochemical actuators based on the BP backbone as well as to promote the development of next-generation soft robots in biomimetic applications.
We present an easy-to-perform and versatile strategy to fabricate hierachically structured BP-CNT materials. Herein, BP provides a layered framework for more rapid ion insertion/ deinsertion, while CNTs improve the interlayer electron conduction and mechanical stability of the BP backbone. In theory, the actuation strain is mainly dominated by the ion induced volume expansion, and the electrode’s structure is more crucial for high performance. In this case, we first created the hierachically structured BP-CNT materials where CNTs are in situ covalently interconnected between BP layers. The present approach is quite general. We can observe that BP provides a layered framework for faster and more ion insertion/deinsertion, and CNTs improve the interlayer electron conduction and mechanical stability of the BP backbone. This designed hierachically structured electrode can largely facilitate actuation performance.
Figure 1 and Figure S1 (Supporting Information) show the schematic synthesis of BP-CNTs in detail. Namely, under programed thermal condensation, the bulk red phosphorus (Figure S2, Supporting Information) could be evaporated and transferred to BP in situ with CNTs under the utilization of mineralizer, forming hierachically structured BP-CNTs. To maintain stable interaction of BP-CNTs under air conditions, chemical passivated functionalization was conducted by immersing BP-CNT samples in 4-nitrobenzene-diazonium (4-NBD) solutions. Hersam et al. previously reported this passivation mechanism of the covalent cross-linking between BP and NBD based on density functional theory (DFT) calculation.[33] It was because the chemisorption of 4-nitrobenzenediazonium on BP is thermodynamically favored[34] that the aryl groups of 4-NBD were covalently bonded through the formation of PC bonds onto a supercell of 16 phosphorus atoms.[33] Consequently, BP-CNTs crystals were chemically passivated by 4-NBD, which could be stably placed in air for 60 d (Figure S3, Supporting Information).
The morphologies and microstructures of as-synthesized BPCNTs are examined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The typical TEM image (Figure 1b) clearly shows that BP nanosheets are wellinterconnected with CNTs, constructing the plane/line structure. As observed closely, CNTs are notably well-embedded in BP flake matrices (Figure 1c). Figure 1d is the high-resolution TEM image of BP-CNTs, demonstrating the well-interlinkage of CNTs in the BP crystalline matrix. The crystal lattice fringe with a spacing of 0.26 nm corresponds to the (040) lattice plane of the BP crystal. Additionally, the lattice line with a spacing of 0.33 nm is equivalent to the (002) plane of CNTs. SEM images (Figure 1e–g) further revealed that the CNTs are interposed within BP nanoflake networks, a finding that is consistent with the results of TEM images. It is worth mentioning that the CNTs embedded in the BP layered framework can alleviate restacking, increase the lamellar conductivity and enhance the mechanical stability of BP. Additionally, through controlling the mass ratios of red phosphorus and CNTs in the thermal reaction, we achieve the optimal hierachically structured BP-CNTs materials (Figure S4, Supporting Information). In practice, the
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1806492
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1806492 (3 of 11)
well-connected and hierarchical porous structure can favor ion diffusion and accumulation.
To investigate the composition and bonding mechanism of BP-CNTs, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted. The XPS survey scan spectra (Figure S5, Supporting Information) and element analysis (Table S2, Supporting Information) showed that the compositions of BP are mainly phosphorus (P, 79.67%) and oxygen (O, 14.92%). A small fraction of carbon (C, 5.41%) in BP is attributed to unavoidable surface adventitious contaminant carbon from the XPS instrument,[26,33] which was observed in the C 1s high-resolution spectrum (Figure 1h). A large portion of O in BP is due to the inevitable exposure of the sample in air for oxidation.[35] After in situ compositing with CNTs, BP-CNTs samples exhibit an increased C content (13.82%), demonstrating the insertion of CNTs in BP networks. Upon chemical passivation, the N element (2.08%) appeared, and C (23.32%) and O (25.21%) elements were also increased in BP-CNTs/4-NBD. After 2 months of storage of the BP-CNTs/4-NBD sample under ambient conditions, there was no significant change in the contents of each element, further demonstrating the good stability of chemically passivated black phosphorus. Additionally, as clearly shown in
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1806492
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1806492 (4 of 11)
the C1s spectra in Figure 1h,i, BP-CNTs samples exhibit a P-C bond peak[25,34] at ≈284 eV compared with BP, demonstrating the existence of a covalent bridge between BP and CNTs under thermal condensation. The chemical modification[33] of 4-NBD with BP-CNTs is illustrated in Figure 1j. Obviously, the intensity of the PC bond peak was strongly increased, and the CN bond peak located at 285.4 eV was presented, evidently proving the functionalization of 4-NBD with BP-CNTs. Figures S6–S8 (Supporting Information) show the P2p XPS spectra of BP, BP-CNTs, and BP-CNTs/4-NBD, respectively. BP exhibited the P 2p3/2 and P 2p1/2 double peaks at 129.7 and 130.5 eV, respectively, corresponding to the characteristic of as-synthesized BP material. Partial oxidation of black phosphorus (POx) is presented at 134 eV.[26,35a,b] The BP-CNTs samples exhibited a sharp PC bond peak at 135 eV, verifying the existence of an in situ bridge between BP and CNTs. Furthermore, the intensity of PC bonds was also enhanced in BP-CNTs/4NBD, implying the successful chemical modification of 4-NBD. Figure S9 (Supporting Information) shows the Raman spectra of as-prepared BP, BP-CNTs and BP-CNTs/4-NBD samples. The peaks at 358, 436, and 464 cm−1 are attributed to A1g, B2g, and A2g modes of BP,[34,36] respectively. Two observable peaks at 1354 and 1596 cm−1 were originated from the D and G bands of CNTs in BP-CNTs. Interestingly, a small peak appeared at ≈695 cm−1 corresponding to PC bonds,[25,34] indicating the in situ bridge between BP and CNTs. When undergoing 4-NBD functionalization, a small peak at ≈850 cm−1 in BP-CNTs/4NBD demonstrates chemical passivation in the sample.
To evaluate the energy-storage value of BP-CNTs materials, the freestanding BP-CNTs/CNTs electrode film was first prepared. Briefly, a mixture of BP-CNTs and CNTs was well dispersed in N,N-dimethylacetamide solution via intense sonication. Next, the gel-like dispersion was casted and dried on a glass substrate, forming the free-standing BP-CNT/CNT film by peeling from the glass. Thereafter, an electrochemical actuator was fabricated by sandwiching the EMIBF4/PVDFHFP (EMIBF4 is 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate (C6H11BF4N2) and PVDF-HFP is poly(vinylidene fluoride-cohexafluoropropylene)) solid-state electrolyte layer with two pieces of free-standing BP-CNT/CNT film via an effective hotpressing process (Figure 2a). The BP-CNT/CNT electrode film exhibits a Young’s modulus of 952.1 MPa with a break elongation of 3.43% (Figure S10, Supporting Information). Considering the good mechanical strength of electrodes, CNTs are alternatively composited with BP-CNTs materials to enhance the flexible stability and electron conduction. The pore size distributions from micro- to mesopores of electrode films are shown in Figure S11 (Supporting Information). Apparently, the BP-CNT/CNT film exhibits two strong peaks at 0.75 and 0.91 nm with a mean pore diameter of 17.41 nm and a pore volume of 0.38 cm−3 g−1, which represents the pore size distribution in a range from 0.64 to 25.5 nm. By comparison, BP/ CNT film has a smaller pore volume of 0.21 cm−3 g−1 with a mean pore diameter of 19.01 nm and a pore size distribution of 0.69–25.5 nm. Because of these main micro/mesopores in hierarchical structure, BP-CNT/CNT film possesses a larger specific surface area (91.62 m2 g−1) than that of BP/CNT film (44.15 m2 g−1). Underlying such a construction, the hierarchical porous structured BP-CNT/CNT electrode layers with high
electric conductivity (192.5 S cm−1) show good interlayer adhesions with the electrolyte layer (Figure 2b), permitting faster ion migration and good mechanical properties of devices.
To estimate the charge-storage performances, cyclic voltammetry (CV) and galvanostatic charge/discharge measurements were carried out using CNT, BP/CNT, and BP-CNT/CNT actuators for comparison. As illustrated in Figure 2c, the pure CNT actuator exhibits a nearly regular rectangular shape, indicating an ideal electric-double-layer capacitive behavior under the applied voltage from −2.5 to 2.5 V. By contrast, BP/CNT actuator displays an apparently developed energy storage performance with redox reaction from an enlarged CV curve. Indeed, the redox pair was attributed to the oxygen functional groups on the surface BP nanoflakes that serves as active sites to improve the charge storage by pseudocapacitance.[26] Although the exact phosphorous-induced pseudocapacitance is unknown presently, the possible redox-reaction equation in BP is speculated by combining phosphorous functional groups interacted with the cations in the electrolyte[37]
P PO : + C H N P PO : C H N / P PO :
+ C H N P PO : C H N 6 11 2
+ 6 11 2 + 2
6 11 2 +
6 11 2 + ( ) ( ) ( ) ( ) − − ↔ − − − − ↔ − −
(1)
Comparing covalently bridged BP-CNTs, it is remarkable to note that BP-CNT/CNT actuator presents the largest CV area with obvious redox peaks, implying the best capacitive performance and efficient electrolyte ion migration throughout hierarchically porous structured electrodes. Additionally, BPCNTs/CNTs exhibit the highest charge/discharge capability with a symmetrical triangular shape (Figure 2d), confirming high reversibility and good coulombic efficiency. The specific capacitances are calculated in Figure 2e. BP-CNT/CNT actuator displays the largest specific capacitance of 321.4 F g−1 at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1, which is better than that of CNTs (102.3 F g−1) and BP/CNTs (201.6 F g−1). By calculating and deducting the differences in the capacitances among BP, BP/CNTs, and BP-CNTs/CNTs, we preliminarily evaluated that the hierarchical structure and redox reaction of BP that contributed to the improvement in the capacitance were 37.27% and 30.9%, respectively. To the best of our knowledge, the specific capacitance value of our actuator exceeds that of most of the reported carbon-material-based electrochemical actuators,[7,13a,16,17,20,38] and can be comparable to those of carbon-material-based solid-state flexible supercapacitors.[39] More specifically, even at such a high scan rate of 1000 mV s−1, BP-CNTs/CNTs can still preserve a large capacitance at 201.4 F g−1, demonstrating a good capability rate. In general, it is the hierarchically porous structure with both high electrical conductivity and electrochemical activity that provides smooth pathways for fast ion transport and accommodation.
To investigate the ion kinetic diffusion and storage in hierarchical-structure-based actuators, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurement was carried out.[40] Figure 2f shows the Nyquist plot, which is analyzed by the equivalent circuit model (Figure S12 and Table S1, Supporting Information), including a depressed semicircle (high-frequency region), Warburg diffusion (medium-frequency region), and intercalation capacitance (low-frequency region). The equivalent circuit contains the following parameter values: R0
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1806492
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1806492 (5 of 11)
represents the inner resistance of the actuator; the element C1/ R1 in parallel is the contact impedance, reflecting the electron conduction from the metal electrode to actuator electrodes; Zw is the diffusion impedance, indicating ion diffusion ability in the actuator; C2 is the intercalation capacitance, which shows that the charge (ions) accumulates in electrode interfaces. According to the simulated analysis, the inner impedances (R0) of CNT, BP/CNT, and BP-CNT/CNT actuators are almost at the same levels, implying the same fabrication and testing process of actuators. The contact impedance (C1/R1) is lower for the BP-CNT/CNT electrode (4.09 mF/2.8 Ω) than for the BP/CNT (3.21 mF/2.88 Ω) and CNT (2.44 mF/3.96 Ω) electrodes. Thus, BP-CNTs/CNTs have a better contact surface with metal electrode, which possesses a faster electron conduction in its stable surface film. Relating to ion diffusion ability (Zw), the BP-CNT/ CNT network shows low ion diffusion impedance of 6.14 Ω and its values are lower than those of BP/CNTs (9.36 Ω) and CNTs (11.32 Ω), demonstrating faster ion diffusion capability in the hierarchical electrode. Furthermore, the time constant τ0, which is determined by the relaxation frequency (f0) at a phase angle of −45°, is defined as the diffused and intercalated capacitive behavior of the ions.[8c,41] Obviously, BP-CNTs/CNTs display lower time constant of 0.59 s than those of BP/CNTs (0.89 s) and CNTs (1.36 s) in Figure S13 (Supporting Information), further demonstrating quicker ion migration and intercalation into hierarchical electrodes. Additionally, it is ideal to observe that the sloped line for BP-CNTs/CNTs at low frequencies is closer to the theoretical vertical line than those of CNTs and BP/CNTs, implying the ideal capacitive and faster ions diffusion behavior. Thus, BP-CNT/CNT actuator has a larger intercalation capacitance (89 mF) than those of CNTs (24 mF) and BP/CNTs (43 mF). Notably, the hierarchical BP-CNT structure can provide an opened 2D-layered structure, smooth pathway, and larger interlayer distance for ion fast transportation and increased accumulation. In addition, the redox activity of BPCNTs can improve the extra ion accommodation in electrodes
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1806492
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1806492 (6 of 11)
for capacitance improvement. Therefore, considering the hierarchical structure, BP-CNT/CNT networks provide favorable path channel and electrochemical activity for faster charge transfer and more accommodation, which are important and beneficial to high energy-storage capability.
We further explored the contents of BP-CNTs affecting energy-storage performance. As shown in Figure S14 (Supporting Information), the BP-CNTs in 15 wt% exhibits the largest CV curves, indicating the best charge transfer and capacitive ability. To further investigate this result, we analyzed the relationship between the specific capacitance and electrical conductivity of the electrodes. As shown in Figure S15 (Supporting Information), when the percentages of BP-CNTs increase from 0, 5 to 15 wt%, the specific capacitances are elevated from 84.9, 130.8 to 270.4 F g−1, whereas the electrical conductivities slowly decrease from 215.1, 204.7 to 192.5 S cm−1, respectively. When the BP-CNTs content further increases to 25 wt%, the specific capacitance decreases to 216.5 F g−1, which results from the severe decline in electrical conductivity (118.6 S cm−1). Therefore, by balancing the electrical conductivity and electrochemical activity, the optimal content of BP-CNTs presents the largest capacitance.
To effectively convert the large charge-storage energy into mechanical motion, a soft cantilever electrochemical actuator was evaluated by attaching it to the electrochemical work station. The typical actuation mechanism is illustrated in Figure 3a. When an electrical field is applied on the actuator, the electrostatic double-layer effect induced ion diffusion and accommodation allow volume expansions of both the cathode and anode.[12b] Because the diameters of cations are larger than those of anions, the actuator exhibits a bending deformation toward the anode.[14] By constructing hierachically structured BP-CNTs/CNTs electrode, larger charge-storage in networks should significantly lead to higher mechanical output than that of pure CNTs. Figure 3b shows the bending responses of actuators based on pure CNTs and BP-CNTs/CNTs at the voltage of ±2.5 V and a frequency of 0.1 Hz. Obviously, the BP-CNT/ CNT actuator demonstrated highly large deformation, and its peak-to-peak bending displacement reached 21.4 mm, which is nearly 3 times higher than that of pure CNTs at 7.2 mm. It is worth noting that the fast and large deformation is attributed to the hierarchical structure facilitating reversible quick ion motion and accumulation, which is consistent with a higher charge-storage and electrostatic-induced actuation mechanism. The actuation displacements can be well controlled by changing the applied voltages (Figure S16, Supporting Information). The wider frequency-dependent (0.1–20 Hz) actuation performance is illustrated in Figure 3c. Under all frequency conditions, BP-CNT/CNT actuator displays impressively higher displacements and strains than that of pure CNT actuator. Remarkably, at the frequency of 0.1 Hz, the BP-CNT/CNT actuator generates a large peak-to-peak strain of 1.67% that exceeds that of pure CNTs at 0.75%. More importantly, especially at the high frequency of 20 Hz, the BP-CNT/CNT actuator can still remain a relatively large actuation strain of 0.29%, while pure CNTs almost lose the frequency response above 5 Hz. As described in the inset of Figure 3c, displacements decrease with increasing excitation frequencies, primarily due to the insufficient time for ion transport into the electrode at higher frequencies.[19] The
long-term stabilities of actuators are evaluated in Figure 3d. Strikingly, BP-CNTs/CNTs actuator has good cyclic stability with slight displacement degradation (9.8%) after continuously operating for 500 000 cycles. This nonobvious decline of displacement may be due to long-term ion reversible intercalation/ de-intercalation decreasing the microstructure and mechanical stability of the electrode network as well as little evaporation of ionic liquids. Furthermore, upon testing the bending displacements of the actuator under relative humidity (RH) and temperature conditions, there are no significant changes in the peak-to-peak strains (Figure S17, Supporting Information). It was revealed that the chemically passivated black phosphorus is sufficiently stable for continuous ion insertion/de-insertion of the electrode network, guaranteeing the durability of actuator devices. To our knowledge, the electro-mechanical performances of our actuator can be comparable or even relatively superior to other ultrathin-material-based untethered actuators, such as a higher frequency response than the thermoresponsive self-folding graphene/poly(N-isopropylacrylamide) actuator,[42] a faster reversible switching speed than the pH- and thermalresponded microsized graphene/silicon dioxide bimorph origami actuator,[43] a lower energy consumption than graphene/ CNTs photoactuators[44] and better deformable controllability than the humidity responded graphene/polypyrrole actuator.[45] This confirms that the large actuation strain and stability depend on highly hierarchically structured networks that are suitable for reliably fast ion motions in/out of electrodes.
Because the actuation strain in the electrochemical actuator is dependent on the electro-mechanical efficiency, the power consumption per generated strain is more meaningful for evaluating the actuation performance. Figure 3e shows that the BP-CNTs/CNTs actuator presents a lower power consumption while generating a large strain. The best power consumption per strain is 0.04 W cm−2 %−1, which marks a significant improvement compared with that of previously reported electrochemical actuators.[3,5,8b,17,18,46] It is evident that the actuator based on the hierarchically structured electrode displays efficient operation with low power consumption, which is vital for next-generation biomimetic robotic techniques. Simultaneously, the BP-CNTs/CNTs actuator also displays a high electro-mechanical transduction efficiency of 7.47%, which is approximately five times larger than that of the CNTs actuator (1.48%). It is worth noting that the higher electromechanical transduction efficiency results from this designed hierarchical-structure-induced larger volume expansion, which is vital to achieving a higher actuation performance of actuator. Figure S18 (Supporting Information) shows that the BP-CNTs/CNTs actuator presents the mechanical strength with both an excellent Young’s modulus of 246.1 MPa and elongation of 5.29%, which are essential for the backend rate capability and work density. To confirm and explore the actuation rate capability, the generated strain and stress rates in response to driving frequencies were evaluated. As shown in Figure S19 (Supporting Information), the BP-CNT/CNT actuator displays a maximum strain speed of 11.57% s−1, exceeding that of various carbon-based electrochemical actuators.[2,3,38,46d] Meanwhile, a high generated stress rate reached 28.48 MPa s−1 (Figure S20, Supporting Information), which is comparable to that of natural and
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1806492
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1806492 (7 of 11)
artificial muscles (30 MPa s−1).[47] Moreover, the maximum energy density of the BP-CNT/CNT actuator realized was as high as 8.48 kJ m−3 (Figure S21, Supporting Information), and the maximum power density was 29.11 kW m−3 (Figure S22, Supporting Information), reaching the level of human skeletal muscles (≈8 kJ m−3).[47] Undoubtedly, compared with the nanostructure alone, this designed unique hierachically structured BP-CNTs with ordered and continuous path channels enables quick ion diffusion and overwhelming accumulation, resulting in the actuator displaying low power consumption, high electromechanical transduction efficiency, fast rate capability, and high work density. In addition to the large actuation strain and fast driving response, actuators also display mechanical output forces. As shown in Figure S23 (Supporting Information), the blocking forces of the BP-CNT/CNT actuator increase with the applied voltage. Impressively, the actuator generated the blocking force of ≈6 mN at a voltage of 2.5 V, showing great progress compared with that of carbon-electrode-based electrochemical actuators (CNTs of 0.3 mN;[5] RGO/CNTs of 0.41 mN;[18] carbon
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1806492
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1806492 (8 of 11)
nitride of 0.93 mN[7]; N–S co-doped graphene/PEDOT:PSS of 1.25 mN[19]; graphdiyne of 3.37 mN[16]). Additionally, the blocking forces of actuators are also elevated when the response time has increased (Figure S24, Supporting Information), and we will improve the value of the force level in our future work.
To demonstrate the large electromechanical energy conversion in situ, scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) study was conducted to characterize the ion-induced volume expansion of the BP electrode.[16] As shown in Figure S25a (Supporting Information), the SECM system consists of one microelectrode probe (10 µm), the redox mediator ferrocenemethanol (FcCH2OH, 10 × 10−3 m) in the EMIBF4 as an electrolyte solution, a reference electrode of Ag/Ag+, a counter electrode of Pt and a substrate electrode film. The SECM image mechanism is dependent on the feedback current when the microelectrode probe scans the substrate electrode. In our system, due to the good electron conduction of the substrate electrode, the feedback current is positive in which the current will be raised when the probe is closer to the substrate electrode. Furthermore, upon applying the voltage on the substrate electrode, the migration and accumulation of ions into substrate electrode generate the volume expansion so that the distance between the microelectrode probe and substrate electrode will decrease and the feedback current will increase. Figure S25b,c (Supporting Information) shows the SECM images of the BP-CNTs/CNTs electrode. Obviously,

© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1806492 (9 of 11)
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1806492
the feedback current increased from −4.56 to −8.63 pA (△ = 4.07 pA) when the voltage of −2.5 V is applied on the electrode. However, the feedback current of CNTs only increased from −4.18 to −5.34 pA (△ = 1.16 pA) when applying the voltage of −2.5 V on the electrode (Figure S25d,e, Supporting Information). This result indicates that the volume expansion of the CNTs electrode can be increased to 3.5 times by introducing black phosphorus in the network. Therefore, the hierachically structured BP-CNTs with 2 D layered skeletons and opened pathways can facilitate fast ion migration and large accumulation in which the actuator shows higher electromechanical energy conversion. To gain insight into the mechanism of high actuation strain in the electrochemical actuator, real time-dependent charge storage was investigated (Figure 4a). Significantly, the BP-CNT/ CNT actuator maintains a much larger real time charge storage (maximum: 0.58 C) than that of the pure CNT actuator (0.19 C), which is in good accordance with the variation of the actuation strain and ion intercalation capacitances. Most importantly, as illustrated in the current–time curve (Figure 4b), there are three independent processes in the BP-CNT/CNT actuator. In the first process, as previously mentioned, the increase in the electric current value originated from the fast charge of the electric double layer, which is capacitive attracted ions. In the second
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1806492 (10 of 11)
process, the redox reaction of BP enables extra charge transfers that accompany consecutive counter ion diffusion, confirming faradic charge enhancement.[48] Admirably, the redox charge transfer is a reversible process and can generate reversible volume expansion of the electrode (inset of Figure 4b). In the third process, owing to both capacitive and faradic charges processes, ions further diffuse into the electrode’s networks, resulting in high actuation performance. Based on the comprehensive results, the schematic illustration of the actuation mechanism model is described in Figure 4c. When the potential is applied on the actuator, fewer EMI+ ions are migrated and accumulated in pure CNT networks, generating lower volume expansion and actuation strain. However, upon introducing hierachically structured BP-CNTs, unique 2D-layered skeletons facilitate faster ions diffusion and flooding accumulation throughout the electrodes,[49] significantly improving the volume expansion of the electrode’s networks. Additionally, the redox reaction of BP with oxygen functional groups increases faradic charge to attract more EMI+ cation intercalation into electrodes so that the actuation strain is further enhanced. Therefore, by considering the hierarchical structure and electrochemical activity of the designed BP-CNT electrodes, the actuator performs outstanding actuation behavior.
To determine the potential applications based on the large actuation deformation, we focused on the proof of concept in which various biomimetic robots are developed by BP-CNT-based electrochemical actuators. Based on the excellent mechanical output force and bending motion, the actuator is first applied as a manipulator to promote the movement of objects much larger than its own (for example, a 0.15 g actuator promotes a 2.9 g table tennis ball in Figure S26 and Movie S1, Supporting Information). In the meantime, an “artificial claw” with a mimetic conceptual gripper was designed by integrating three actuators as soft legs. Figure 5a and Movie S2 (Supporting Information) show that the robot can tightly grasp, lift, transport and put down lightweight objects (153 mg) under the response time of 15 s and is larger and heavier than that of the gripper itself (82 mg). In addition to soft-grasped locomotion, a flying robot prototype that mimics wing vibration of a butterfly, has been constructed by binding two actuators in parallel (Figure 5b and Movie S3, Supporting Information). A fast wing-like vibrating motion seems to be flying way from the bondage of copper wires at a high frequency of 8 Hz, revealing outstanding promise for biomimetic aircraft and insects. Interestingly, a colorful bionic flower was designed and fabricated by four actuators as colorful petals that were first painted with different colors (Figure 5c and Movie S4, Supporting Information). When a voltage is applied on the bionic flower, folding and blooming processes are achieved at the frequency of 0.05 Hz. To develop the useful proof-of-model, a hand-shaped robot was also designed by fixing five independent actuators with separated circuits (Figure 5d and Movie S5, Supporting Information). Each finger can move separately so that the robot can implement various gestures, which vividly imitating the action of a human hand without the aid of any mechanical equipment. Considering of those features, the BP-CNTsbased electrochemical actuator has shown straightforward evidence for great potential in biomimetic applications.
In summary, this method is versatile, and various types of electrochemical actuators could be designed with hierachically structured black phosphorous covalently bridged to carbon nanotube materials. Both small actuators and smart robots may be used in this method. This technique may yield high actuation performance, including low power consumption/strain, a large peak-to-peak deformation, a controlled frequency response, faster strain and stress rates, high power and energy densities, and excellent cycling stability. Various derived covalently bridged BP-CNT materials with higher electrochemical–mechanical properties, are available by the designed open layered structure, strengthen lamellar conductivity and enhance the mechanical stability and excess faradic charge transfer. By exploiting these remarkable features, various bioinspired robots based on electrochemical actuators have been first realized such as the artificial-claw, wing-vibrating, bionicflower, and hand actuators. Considering these outstanding achievements, we anticipate that the black-phosphorous-based actuator and its biomimetic robotic design will advance newgeneration electrode architecture as well as guide the substantial progress in the fields of artificial muscles, soft robotics, and biomedical microdevices.
